title: Adding Gizmo frontend

content.raw: I'll get on the dataset today!
content.html: I'll get on the dataset today!

content.raw:
As a followup on this, I uploaded the dataset a couple weeks ago.  It is available here:

http://yt-project.org/data/

as ``FIRE_M12i_ref11``
content.html:
As a followup on this, I uploaded the dataset a couple weeks ago. It is available here:

http://yt-project.org/data/

as FIRE_M12i_ref11

content.raw: In the hangout, we suggested that this be the "GIZMO" dataset.
content.html: In the hangout, we suggested that this be the "GIZMO" dataset.

content.raw: er, frontend.  Or "gizmo".  Whatever.
content.html: er, frontend. Or "gizmo". Whatever.

Also, I said this in the hangout, but I am going to write it down here, too -- I personally think that the best reasons for having a new frontend are related to the fundamental way data is represented by a simulation code, or by situations where simple runtime changes can't account for IO/indexing differences. Representing gizmo data differently than Gadget data is an actual thing we could do, so having them be separate is a good idea, but I don't think we should call it "fire" since it's a subset of all possible gizmo simulations (and one that is easily recognized.)

By that same token, I am no longer certain that I think eagles and owls should be their own frontend, since they can be detected and dealt with at runtime (and indeed are, as evidenced in the structure of those frontends.)

Robert Thompson has noted that Gizmo data, confusingly, can be run in SPH mode without there being any way to disentangle the types, which is ultimately a problem we don't need to solve.

content.raw: I think moving OWLS/EAGLE back into the gadget front end is a fantastic idea.  Having GIZMO as it's own front end is a great idea for _some_ cases.  I'm thinking particularly when one turns on adaptive softening for all particles that data will be present in the dataset and will give us new ways to visualize/smooth things which is NOT present in gadget.  However, when one runs a run-of-the-mill gizmo sim with no fancy features it should basically fall back to the gadget front end functionality (if that makes sense?).
content.html: I think moving OWLS/EAGLE back into the gadget front end is a fantastic idea. Having GIZMO as it's own front end is a great idea for some cases. I'm thinking particularly when one turns on adaptive softening for all particles that data will be present in the dataset and will give us new ways to visualize/smooth things which is NOT present in gadget. However, when one runs a run-of-the-mill gizmo sim with no fancy features it should basically fall back to the gadget front end functionality (if that makes sense?).

description:
This PR adds a frontend for the FIRE simulations and removes some slightly incorrect FIRE-related fields definitions from the SPH frontend.  Remaining to-dos:

* supply a sample dataset (@chummels is working on this)

* tests

* docs
